texts.definition: Decremental effects from actions or events that can lead to negative consequences.
markups: <style="Definition">Decremental effects from actions or events that can lead to negative consequences.</style>

In games, <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> is an indication that players have failed to avoid the actions of enemies or dangerous objects in the game. The effects of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> in most games are minor; it is mainly used as an indicator of how many times one may fail before more serious effects occur.

Few <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> make all hits instantaneous kills. Rather they require players to succeed with shots or strikes several times, each one giving <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>, before killing their opponents. One exception includes the ability to kill instantaneously through headshots, and can found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>.

Roleplaying games, both in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> and in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop</link></style> varieties such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, often have detailed rules for how <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can occur and what effects it has, e.g. dividing character's bodies into different hit areas and having different consequences for taking <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> in each area.

In the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/RoboRally">RoboRally</link></style>, the first points of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> reduces the number of cards received each round. However, more <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> makes some earlier cards be repeated each turn, and this severely limits the freedom of player actions each turn. Even more <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> destroys the robot.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> effects consist of deciding what causes it, how it is measured or what effects it causes, and who or what can be affected by it (see <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> for notes on reversing the effects of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>). Most design where taking <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> once does not kill makes use <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, so considering that pattern is often relevant when designing games where <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can occur.

<style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> are an obvious choice for game entities that should cause <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>, but other common examples include <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> (when they can be used to hit other entities) and <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> (when they can be used as improvised <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto:%20San%20Andreas">Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> use all these options (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> too except for <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> being ineffective). <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> is another source for <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> but in this case, the <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> they cause is often what defines them (it should be noted that <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that cause <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can together be <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>). Taking another perspective, the cause for receiving <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can be failing to detect <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style>, failing to succeed in <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals, or failing in <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> to avoid <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style> are in this respect similar to <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> except that they may what moves instead of players' <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, and if this makes it impossible to hinder the <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> from moving this is a type of <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>. Less common reasons for <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> include not being <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style> or making <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style> perform actions where the needed <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> are described in terms of <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>.

The most common type of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> is simply a reduction of <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, sometimes called hit points but the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> shows how <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can be used to reduce both <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> characteristics. <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> can also stand in as an alternative. In all these cases the <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> are <style="Link"><link="energy-penalties">Energy Penalties</link></style>. However, other effects such as forced <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style>, reduced <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, loss of aiming in games with <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> can be used to create <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>, and these can be used together with reductions of <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> to create <style="Link"><link="critical-hits">Critical Hits</link></style> (another easier way is simply to increase the <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> provided). Independent of how the <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> was caused its numerical values can either be fixed or be determined by a function. Fixed <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> values give <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> while functions can be used to create <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> and increase the potential interest for each time <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> is received. If <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> comes as effect of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, the severity of these are increased but the possibility of players' having <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> may be negatively affected. In games with <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>, an option for <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> is directly to cause <style="Link"><link="life-penalties">Life Penalties</link></style> rather than do it as the effects of depleting some <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> (most commonly <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>).

The basic amount of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> give is typically a fixed value or a combination of <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style>. How much <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> is actually given can however be modulated by in many ways. One way is to introduce <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> aspects through that parts that are more difficult to hit suffer more <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> if hit. An example of this is the possibility to do instantaneous kills with head shots in first-person shooters such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> give extra <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> if the attack is of a specific type or hits specific areas, and knowing about this is <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> if this is not obvious (this is often the case with <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> is another option where succeeding with them result in increased <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>. <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style> can be used to regulate if games should have <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> or to achieve <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style>. The amount of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> taken can often be diminish or cancelled by pre-emptive or counter actions. Examples of counter actions include using <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> (e.g. playing "blocking" <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Games</link></style>), or performing blocking or parrying maneuvers. Examples of pre-emptive actions include donning <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> or activating <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> (e.g. activating "übercharges" in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%202">Team Fortress 2</link></style>). Permanent <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> reduce the presence of the <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> pattern but does not have to eliminate it completely if several different types of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> exist.

<style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> are common entities that can be affected by <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>, but games can also let <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> be affected by <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> if they are <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>. Typically, not all objects can be destroyed; a quite common solution is to make it possible to destroy the results of <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>.

The amount of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> received is usually indicated by <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> in order for players to perceive the severity of the <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> and gain knowledge about what caused the <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>. When objects in gameplay environments have been damaged, they may be augmented with <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> to show their status. In both cases, <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can cause <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> to let players have <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> about what events have taken place.

<style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> is a form of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> in games. Since the effect of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> usually has <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>, both the possibility of <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> and actually suffering <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can be causes of <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can come in many different forms or have different effect, knowing about these represent <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>. When <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> requires player skill, <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can provide a system component to create <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>.

While accumulated <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can make <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> possible in games, it can also be used to increase granularity to <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> by making attacks not directly lose <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>. This also allows modulation of <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals so that not one single successful attack eliminates an <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemy</link></style> but rather several successes are required. It can also introduce <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style> to <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> and destruction to <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>, creating <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> consideration for using <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> when the results of this activity can be destroyed. In general, how much <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can be received before more severe <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> are inflicted modulates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> choices players do when they are under risk of taking <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style>.

Like <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> can be seen as a measure of how many times one may fail avoiding bad effects in a game before a more severe <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style> is imposed. In this sense, it can be seen as a <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style>. However, <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> works on a smaller scale and may have no effect on player's <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> until the accumulated <style="CurrentLink">Damage</style> is translated into another form of <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalty</link></style>, typically the loss of <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> or the destruction of <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>.

<style="H4">with <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style></style>

<style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="variable-accuracy">Variable Accuracy</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="moveable-tiles">Moveable Tiles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="critical-hits">Critical Hits</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style>
